Iâ€™ve been recently inspired by Greta Van Fleet, basically the latest band since the Black Keys that can truly rock. This naturally has gotten me listening to Led Zeppelin again as well, and Iâ€™ve even been getting back to writing a few classic rock style tunes with my acoustic guitar. This was a neat little project I threw together in order to try to generate some new lyrics, and also to see what could make those Led Zeppelin / Greta Van Fleet lyrics just soâ€¦

Yep, if anyone out there has been following along in my blogging adventures, youâ€™ll know that Iâ€™m lazy. Anything that can be automated, Iâ€™m going to try to automate it! (Or in the very least, partially automate it or find a tool to use to make my life easier.) Actually, the entire concept of this post reflects my laziness: Iâ€™m willing to make a tool that generates lyrics
me before I visit my buddy this summer as we prepare to write an EP together! (Yikes! - Iâ€™ll let you know how
Getting the List of Song Names
Thereâ€™s this neat tool that I found that extracts lists from Wikipedia pages:
, built by Gregor Weichbrodt. Nice one, Gregor! Andâ€¦ (yes you can see where this is going) of course, Wikipedia has a list for everything
(no, that is not actually trademarked) And guess what? They have a â€œList of songs recorded by Led Zeppelinâ€ page!
Throw that into Gregorâ€™s tool, and youâ€™ve got your .csv data, which with 5 seconds work with Sublime text, becomes our song list:

Not so bad- weâ€™ve retrieved what is the vast majority of Led Zeppelinâ€™s lyrics in a matter of minutes. However, Iâ€™m still too lazy to get these lyrics by hand - Iâ€™m not gonna add â€˜em. ðŸ˜‚
So weâ€™ve retrieved our data. I wanted to count most common words as a simple start to analyze these lyrics. So, relying heavily on
(Natural Language Toolkit) we build a corpus from all the lyrics, remove the stopwords, and count the occurrences with Pythonâ€™s
The first plot, of the top 25 most common words, looks like this:
